I was reading about how a map from a set can induce a map from a suitable quotient of that set. I'm wondering if this situation can be generalized to a statement about equivalent categories.

My (short) question is at the end, preceded by some (longer) motivation.

As the motivating example (following Jacobson's "Basic Algebra I"), let SSS be a set and let EEE be an equivalence relationship on SSS. Let α:S→T\alpha: S \to Tα:S→T be a function to a set TTT that is compatible with EEE, in the sense that if any aaa and bbb in SSS are equivalent under EEE then α(a)=α(b)\alpha(a) = \alpha(b)α(a)=α(b). We then define a map v:S→S/Ev: S \to S/Ev:S→S/E which sends s∈Ss \in Ss∈S to its equivalence class [s][s][s] under the equivalence relationship EEE. Given α\alphaα and vvv, I believe there is then a unique α′:S/E→T\alpha': S/E \to Tα′:S/E→T so that α′∘v=α\alpha' \circ v = \alphaα′∘v=α. This map sends an equivalence class [s][s][s] to the value α(s)\alpha(s)α(s), and this is well-defined because if s,t∈[s]s,t \in [s]s,t∈[s] then α(s)=α(t)\alpha(s) = \alpha(t)α(s)=α(t).

I believe that the set SSS together with the equivalence relationship EEE induces a groupoid. The objects of the groupoid are the elements of SSS, and there is a morphism from aaa to bbb if aaa is equivalent to bbb under EEE. I'll refer to this induced category as SES_ESE​. We can also view TTT as a discrete category, where the objects are the elements of TTT. Then a functor α:SE→T\alpha: S_E \to Tα:SE​→T is a function from the set SSS to the set TTT such that if there is a morphism m:a→bm: a \to bm:a→b, then α(a)=α(b)\alpha(a) = \alpha(b)α(a)=α(b). So, a function α:S→T\alpha: S \to Tα:S→T that is compatible with an equivalence relationship on EEE corresponds to a functor α:SE→T\alpha: S_E \to Tα:SE​→T.

We can also view S/ES/ES/E as a discrete category. I think S/ES/ES/E and SES_ESE​ are equivalent categories, with v:SE→S/Ev: S_E \to S/Ev:SE​→S/E and some inclusion functor u:S/E→SEu: S/E \to S_Eu:S/E→SE​ (which sends each equivalence class to an element in that equivalence class) providing an equivalence.

So, I think the situation is as follows. We have a functor α:SE→T\alpha: S_E \to Tα:SE​→T, and a category S/ES/ES/E which is equivalent to SES_ESE​ by an equivalence with data v:SE→S/Ev: S_E \to S/Ev:SE​→S/E and u:S/E→SEu: S/E \to S_Eu:S/E→SE​. Then there is a unique functor α′:S/E→T\alpha': S/E \to Tα′:S/E→T so that α′∘v=α\alpha' \circ v = \alphaα′∘v=α. I am wondering if this situation generalizes.

My question is this: If v:S→S′v: S \to S'v:S→S′ and u:S′→Su: S' \to Su:S′→S is an equivalence of categories, and α:S→T\alpha :S \to Tα:S→T is a functor, is there a unique α′\alpha'α′ so that α′∘v=α\alpha' \circ v = \alphaα′∘v=α, or at least α′∘v≅α\alpha' \circ v \cong \alphaα′∘v≅α? My guess is the answer is "yes", with α′≅α∘u\alpha' \cong \alpha \circ uα′≅α∘u, but I don't understand the algebra for manipulating equivalences well enough to prove this yet.

Everything you said about sets and equivalence relations sounds correct! And before getting into your question, I want to say that a lot of what you did generalizes from Set\mathsf{Set}Set to other sufficiently nice categories. I believe any [[regular category]] will be good enough.

Let me list some examples, since the general definition is a bit scary! Examples of regular categories include the category of groups or abelian groups or vector spaces or graphs (defined the way category theorists define graphs, aka [[quivers]]).

We can define and work with equivalence relations in any regular category C\mathsf{C}C! An equivalence relation on X∈CX \in \mathsf{C}X∈C is a special sort of groupoid internal to C\mathsf{C}C - so instead of getting groupoids from equivalence relations the way you just did, we define an equivalence relation to be a special sort of groupoid - but living in C\mathsf{C}C, not Set\mathsf{Set}Set.

In any regular category, given an object XXX with an equivalence relation EEE on it, we can get a new object X/EX/EX/E.

Furthermore, in any regular category, a morphism f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y determines an equivalence relation EEE on XXX. The naive idea is that elements of XXX that get mapped by fff to the same element of YYY are equivalent. But we are able to express this idea without mentioning "elements"!

Then we can form the quotient object X/EX/EX/E, and fff becomes equal to the composite of two morphisms:

X→X/E→Y X \to X/E \to YX→X/E→Y

The naive idea is that first we scrunch down elements of XXX that map to the same element of YYY, and then we map them to YYY. This idea is made precise here.

TL;DR: while you are interested in connecting equivalence relations on sets to category theory, there is also something else people like to do: generalize the theory of equivalence relations from Set\mathsf{Set}Set to other categories!

Okay, now your actual question:

My question is this: If v:S→S′v: S \to S'v:S→S′ and u:S′→Su: S' \to Su:S′→S is an equivalence of categories, and α:S→T\alpha :S \to Tα:S→T is a functor, is there a unique α′\alpha'α′ so that α′∘v=α\alpha' \circ v = \alphaα′∘v=α, or at least α′∘v≅α\alpha' \circ v \cong \alphaα′∘v≅α? My guess is the answer is "yes", with α′≅α∘u\alpha' \cong \alpha \circ uα′≅α∘u, but I don't understand the algebra for manipulating equivalences well enough to prove this yet.
A functor α′\alpha'α′ with α′∘v=α\alpha' \circ v = \alphaα′∘v=α may not exist. Find a counterexample where all the categories involved have at most 2 objects!

This is just an example of a general lesson: equations between functors are evil; natural isomorphisms are better.

Morality aside, if you are working with equivalences, which are wisely not defined using equations between functors, you will have trouble getting equations to work.

A functor α′\alpha'α′ with α′∘v≅α\alpha' \circ v \cong \alphaα′∘v≅α does exist, and you guessed what it could be: α′=α∘u\alpha' = \alpha \circ uα′=α∘u. Check that this works!

(This equation is not evil since I'm defining α′\alpha'α′ this way! [[Definitional equality]] is okay.)

But a functor α′\alpha'α′ with α′∘v≅α\alpha' \circ v \cong \alphaα′∘v≅α is typically not unique. Morally, that's because uniqueness here would be stating an equation between functors, and that's evil. But it's good to find a small counterexample.
But this is okay, since a functor α′\alpha'α′ with α′∘v≅α\alpha' \circ v \cong \alphaα′∘v≅α is unique up to natural isomorphism.
Awesome, thanks for your very interesting response! When I have energy, I'll have to take a look at several of the things you've mentioned, and type up something about them in this thread.

Let SSS be a category with two isomorphic objects and the minimum of morphisms, and let S′S'S′ be category with a single object and just its identity morphism. SSS and S′S'S′ are equivalent. Now let T=ST=ST=S. We have a functor α\alphaα from SSS to TTT (the identity functor) that has two objects in its image. However, there is only one object in S′S'S′ so there can be no functor α′:S→T\alpha': S \to Tα′:S→T so that α=α′∘v\alpha = \alpha' \circ vα=α′∘v for some v:S→S′v: S \to S'v:S→S′ that is part of an equivalence of SSS and S′S'S′.

It's interesting to notice that we can add or delete objects from an isomorphism class of objects and still obtain an equivalent category.

A functor α′\alpha'α′ with α′∘v≅α\alpha' \circ v \cong \alphaα′∘v≅α does exist, and you guessed what it could be: α′=α∘u\alpha' = \alpha \circ uα′=α∘u. Check that this works!

Let α′=α∘u\alpha' = \alpha \circ uα′=α∘u. Then α′∘v=(α∘u)∘v=α∘(u∘v)\alpha' \circ v = (\alpha \circ u) \circ v = \alpha \circ (u \circ v)α′∘v=(α∘u)∘v=α∘(u∘v).
And this is where I get stuck. I know that u∘v≅IdSu \circ v \cong Id_Su∘v≅IdS​, so what I want to say next is that α′∘v=α∘(u∘v)≅α∘(IdS)=α\alpha ' \circ v = \alpha \circ (u \circ v) \cong \alpha \circ (Id_S) = \alphaα′∘v=α∘(u∘v)≅α∘(IdS​)=α.

It's interesting to notice that we can add or delete objects from an isomorphism class of objects and still obtain an equivalent category.

Yes. In fact that's the only way to get equivalent categories.

This is definitely a good thing to show! Here's one way to approach it: if you have functors F,G:C→DF,G: \mathsf{C} \to \mathsf{D}F,G:C→D, a natural transformation α:F⇒G\alpha : F \Rightarrow Gα:F⇒G, and a functor H:D→EH: \mathsf{D} \to \mathsf{E}H:D→E you can cook up a natural transformation

H∙α:H∘F→H∘G H \bullet \alpha: H \circ F \to H \circ GH∙α:H∘F→H∘G

This trick is called [[whiskering]] and you can show it obeys

H∙(αβ)=(H∙α)(H∙β) H \bullet (\alpha \beta) = (H \bullet \alpha)(H \bullet \beta)H∙(αβ)=(H∙α)(H∙β)

Here I'm using plain old juxtaposition to denote composition of natural transformations.
I hope you see why this implies what you're trying to show now.

After you learn how to compose functors and how to compose natural transformations, the next thing to study is whiskering of functors by natural transformations, and the rules obeyed by whiskering. Above I'm talking about "right whiskering", but there's also "left whiskering". Once you have all this material under control you'll be able to do a lot with functors and natural transformations!

John Baez said:

We can define and work with equivalence relations in any regular category C\mathsf{C}C! An equivalence relation on X∈CX \in \mathsf{C}X∈C is a special sort of groupoid internal to C\mathsf{C}C - so instead of getting groupoids from equivalence relations the way you just did, we define an equivalence relation to be a special sort of groupoid - but living in C\mathsf{C}C, not Set\mathsf{Set}Set.

In any regular category, given an object XXX with an equivalence relation EEE on it, we can get a new object X/EX/EX/E.

Furthermore, in any regular category, a morphism f:X→Yf: X \to Yf:X→Y determines an equivalence relation EEE on XXX. The naive idea is that elements of XXX that get mapped by fff to the same element of YYY are equivalent. But we are able to express this idea without mentioning "elements"!

Then we can form the quotient object X/EX/EX/E, and fff becomes equal to the composite of two morphisms:

X→X/E→Y X \to X/E \to YX→X/E→Y

So, the precise conditions on the category here are a bit confusing.

  1. We can define internal equivalence relations (sometimes called [[congruences]]) in any category with finite limits.
  2. To construct the quotient X/EX/EX/E of an arbitrary internal equivalence relation, the category has to be not just regular but a (Barr) [[exact category]].
  3. However, the equivalence relation determined by a morphism fff (sometimes called its [[kernel pair]]) exists in any category with finite limits, and it has a quotient in any regular category.

Essentially, a regular category is one that has well-behaved "image factorizations" X↠X/E↪YX \twoheadrightarrow X/E \hookrightarrow YX↠X/E↪Y, which in particular entails that the intermediate object X/EX/EX/E is the quotient of the kernel pair of the morphism. But it may not have quotients of arbitrary equivalence relations that don't arise as the kernel pair of anything.

Horizontal composition has always scared me. So it's good to start getting over that fear a bit. It seems very useful!
Yes, all this looks good!

When you understand the rules governing horizontal and vertical composition of natural transformations - there aren't many! - and the rules governing whiskering - which is a special case! - then you're really up and running when it comes to dealing with Cat\mathbf{Cat}Cat.

(Your remarks about small categories is not really relevant here; all this stuff works for large categories too, you just have to pay the cops a bribe to let you do it.)
